Award.AwardTitle: International Workshop on Partial Differential Equations and Complex Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "International Workshop on Partial Differential Equations and Complex Analysis" that will be held August 13-17 at the Universidade Federal de Sao Carlos in Brazil. The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of Several Complex Variables and Partial Differential Equations.

A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF and the like an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: http://www.mat.puc-rio.br/~pimentel/pdeca2018/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UFSCar International Workshop on Partial Differential Equations and Complex Analysis took place at the Universidade Federal de Sao Carlos (UFSCar), in Sao Carlos, Brazil from August 13, 2018 -- August 17, 2018. This conference was an official satellite conference of the the 2018 International Congress of Mathematics (ICM) in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The ICM is the largest and most prestigious conference in the world. Its Official Satellite Conferences are also quite prestigious and routinely attract the preeminent mathematicians in the world. 

 

The focus of the our satellite conference was the interplay between Harmonic Analysis, Partial Differential Equations, Several Complex Variables, and Geometric Measure Theory 

The interface between branches of analysis and PDE has witnessed a number of recent breakthroughs, and the workshop provided a much-needed forum for the dissemination of new ideas and results and as well as the identification of directions for future development. The presence of such a concentration of distinguished mathematicians in Brazil on the occasion of the ICM was an ideal opportunity for bringing this plan to fruition.

 

The workshop featured five or six lectures a day, leaving significant time for collaboration and discussion in small groups. Additionally, we had

problem sessions, a lunch for graduate students,  a lunch for the women participants, a special lecture on the ICTP, and a conference banquet.
